head.title: Surely, We Can Improve on Trial by Jury

hedline.hl1: Surely, We Can Improve on Trial by Jury

block.p: Dec. 23 letters by Gerry E. Feinberg and Benjamin Brafman, both lawyers, point out two flaws in our system of trial by jury -- hardship to jurors and lengthy trials. These are not the only problems, nor the worst.

Dec. 23 letters by Gerry E. Feinberg and Benjamin Brafman, both lawyers, point out two flaws in our system of trial by jury -- hardship to jurors and lengthy trials. These are not the only problems, nor the worst.

Trial by jury is costly, unwieldy, wasteful and time consuming. Its use was developed in England and other European states during the Middle Ages as a response to autocratic rule and later as a safeguard of personal and political liberty. Today it is largely an anachronism and obsolete.
There is indeed a viable alternative: its abolition.

No system of judicial administration can claim perfection. But a panel of carefully selected judges (the number depending on the nature and gravity of the case), functioning unfettered by the burden and responsibility of a jury and subject to appellate review, is more capable of rendering a speedy determination in keeping with the law and the facts.
By dint of background, training, experience and professional and moral disciplines, such a tribunal is apt to reach a just and equitable decision, and less likely to commit a miscarriage of justice.

This is in contrast to the unpredictable, unsophisticated, untrained, undisciplined and frequently prejudiced jury of 12 lay peers. At best, the jury is a drag upon the judicial process. At worst, it is an insidious peril. S. EZRA AUSTERN Brooklyn, Dec. 27 1994 The writer is a lawyer.
